facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 19 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 19 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated April 11, 1957 in Special Civil Application No. 3170 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 11, 1957, of Bombay High Court, in Special Civil Application No. 3170 of 1956.

facts.text: Tenancy case instituted by appellant against respondents in Court of Mamlatdar Raver, East Khandesh, Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of a tenancy case instituted by the appellant against his tenants the respondents in the Court of the Mamlatdar Raver  East Khandesh , in the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: Property consists of agricultural lands Survey Nos. 32 and 38 in village Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: The property in suit companysists of agricultural lands, Survey Nos. 32 and 38, situated in the village Raipur.

facts.text: Respondents executed rent note in favour of appellant on February 5, 1943 for five years at annual rent Rs. 785/-

anchor.surface_text: The respondents had executed a rent numbere in respect of these lands in favour of the appellant on February 5, 1943. The period for which the rent numbere was executed was five years and the rent agreed to be paid annually was Rs. 785/-

facts.text: Lease would have expired on March 31, 1948 in ordinary course.

anchor.surface_text: In ordinary companyrse the lease would have expired on March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 applied to East Khandesh on April 11, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: However, before the lease expired, on April 11, 1946 the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939  Bombay Act XXIX of 1939  was applied to the area of the East Khandesh where the lands are situated,

facts.text: Section 23(1)(b) of Bombay Tenancy Act 1939 extended lease to ten years, expiring March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and in companysequence as a result of s. 23  1   b  of the said Act the five years period stipulated in the rent numbere was statutorily extended to ten years the result was that under the said statutory provision the rent numbere in favour of the respondents would have expired on March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act LXVII of 1948 came into force during subsistence of tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: During the subsistence of the tenancy thus statutorily extended the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act LXVII of 1948 came into force.

facts.text: Appellant gave notice to respondents on March 11, 1952 intimating expiry on March 31, 1953 and demanding possession.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1952 the appellant gave numberice to the respondents intimating to them that the period of the rent numbere executed by them which had been statutorily extended would expire on March 31, 1953 and calling upon them to deliver possession of the lands to him immediately thereafter.

facts.text: Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952 came into operation on January 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Before the numberice companyld be effectively enforced on the expiration of the period of the lease, however, Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952 came into operation on January 12, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant instituted tenancy proceedings on April 4, 1953 for possession.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1953 the appellant instituted the present tenancy proceedings for obtaining possession of the lands.

facts.text: Mamlatdar rejected appellant's claim for lack of statutory notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar who tried the proceedings rejected the appellants claim on the ground that he had number terminated the tenancy of the respondents as required by law in that he had number given the statutory numberice making the prescribed relevant averments in that behalf.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal against Mamlatdar's decision dismissed by appellate authority.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred an appeal against the decision of the Mamlatdar but the appellate authority agreed with the view taken by the Mamlatdar and dismissed his appeal.

facts.text: Bombay Revenue Tribunal allowed appellant's revisional application, held amendments not retrospective, entitled to eject.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute was then taken by the appellant before the Bombay Revenue Tribunal by way of a revisional application and the revisional application succeeded. The Tribunal held that the relevant amendments on which the Mamlatdar and the appellate authority had relied in dismissing the appellants claim were number retrospective and that the appellant was entitled to eject the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition under Art. 227 in Bombay High Court challenging Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: This order of the Revenue Tribunal was challenged by the respondents by a petition filed by them under Art. 227 of the Constitution in the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed writ petition, held amendments retrospective, set aside Tribunal order, restored appellate authority order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has allowed the writ petition and held that the relevant amendments are retrospective in operation and that the appellant is number entitled to eject the respondents. On that view the order passed by the Revenue Tribunal has been set aside and that of the appellate authority restored.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 29, 1961 by Gajendragadkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant claims amendments of 1952 not retrospective, notice of 1952 sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: His case, however, is that the technical requirements of a valid numberice prescribed by the amending Act do number apply to his claim inasmuch as the relevant provisions of the amending Act are number retrospective in operation.

facts.text: High Court held amendments retrospective, dismissed appellant's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that this companytention is number well-founded and so the appellants claim for ejectment has been dismissed.

facts.text: Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952 repealed s.14(2), amended s.5, added s.5(3).

anchor.surface_text: This Act repealed s. 14 2  and amended s. 5 and added sub-s.  3  to it.

facts.text: Effect of amendment: tenancy terminable only with one year's notice on ground of bona fide personal cultivation as main income source.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly stated the effect of this amendment was that the tenancy of the respondents, who were till then ordinary tenants as distinct from protected tenants, companyld number be terminated on the expiry of their tenancy except by giving one years numberice and that too on the ground that the lands were required by the landlord for bona fide personal cultivation and that the income of the said lands would be the main source of income of the landlord.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds amendments apply, appellant must give valid notice as per 1952 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is whether the appellant is entiled to eject the respondents even without companyplying with the statutory requirement as to the valid numberice prescribed by the amending Act XXXIII of 1952.

facts.text: Lease extended automatically by proviso to s.5(1) for further ten years from March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, before the lease in favour of the respondents companyld expire on March 31, 1953, by virtue of the proviso to s. 5 1  of the amending Act of 1952 it got extended for ten years,
under Art. 227 of the Constitution in the Bombay High Court.

concepts.interpretation: Tenancy terminates at end of ten years unless held over.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso to s.5(1) extended tenancy before March 31, 1953 expiry; notice given before extension insufficient; right to possession vests only on actual termination

arguments.claim: Amending Act extended lease automatically for further ten years before expiry on March 31, 1953; old notice ineffective; must give valid notice under statute

anchor.surface_text: In other words, before the lease in favour of the respondents could expire on March 31, 1953, by virtue of the proviso to s. 5 1  of the amending Act of 1952 it got extended for ten years,

arguments.claim: Right to eject arises only on termination of tenancy, which did not occur on March 31, 1953 due to statutory extension; amending Act deprived right before accrual by requiring valid notice

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is necessary to bear in mind that the right of the appellant to eject the respondents would arise only on the termination of the tenancy and in the present case it would have been available to him on March 31, 1953 if the statutory provision had not in the meanwhile extended the life of the tenancy.

arguments.claim: Distinction between existing right and vested right: statute operating in future not retrospective even if affecting existing rights

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it is relevant to distinguish between an existing right and a vested right. Where a statute operates in future it cannot be said to be retrospective merely because within the sweep of its operation all existing rights are included.

arguments.claim: Precedent in West v. Gwynne: Act affecting future operation on existing leases not retrospective

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Buckley, L. J. in West v. Gwynne retrospective operation is one matter and interference with existing rights is another. If an Act provides that as at a past date the law shall be taken to have been that which it was not that Act I understand to be retrospective.

arguments.claim: Jivabhai Purshottam v. Chhagan Karson approves retrospective operation of s.34(2A) of 1952 Act; imposes new limitation on right to possession post-notice expiry

anchor.surface_text: A similar question had been raised for the decision of this Court in Jivabhai Purshottam v. Chhagan Karson in regard to the retrospective operation of s. 34 2  a  of the said amending Act XXXIII of 1952 and this Court has approved of the decision of the full Bench of the Bombay High Court on that point in Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaberbhai Bhikabhai.

arguments.claim: Sakharam case on s.88 prospectivity not analogous to 1952 Act provisions

anchor.surface_text: In that case the Court was called upon to consider the question as to whether the provisions of s. 88 of Bombay Act LXVII of 1948 were retrospective in operation or not, and it has been held that the said provisions are prospective.

arguments.court_reasoning: Position re s.88 not similar to 1952 amendments

arguments.claim: Decision in Jivabhai against contention but rely on Sakharam

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bengeri, for the appellant, fairly conceded that the decision of this Court in Jivabhais case was against his contention but he purported to rely on another decision of this Court in Sakharam alias Bapusaheb Narayan Sanas v. Manikchand Motichand Shah.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: visions companytained in s. 88 can be said to be analogous or similar to the position with regard to the relevant provisions of the amending Act XXXII

holdings.text: before the lease in favour of the respondents could expire on March 31, 1953, by virtue of the proviso to s. 5(1) of the amending Act of 1952 it got extended for ten years

anchor.surface_text: In other words, before the lease in favour of the respondents could expire on March 31, 1953, by virtue of the proviso to s. 5 1  of the amending Act of 1952 it got extended for ten years,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.5(1) deems tenancy renewed for further ten years subject to ss.5(2),(3), applying immediately to prevent expiry on 31.3.1953

holdings.text: there can be no doubt that as a result of the amending Act of 1952 the expiration of the lease did not take place on March 31, 1953 as had been anticipated by the appellant when he gave notice on March 11, 1952

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there can be no doubt that as a result of the amending Act of 1952 the expiration of the lease did not take place on March 31, 1953 as had been anticipated by the appellant when he gave notice on March 11, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory extension intervened before anticipated expiry date, rendering prior notice ineffective

holdings.text: In order to put an end to the tenancy thus statutorily safeguarded the appellant has to follow the course prescribed by the amending statute and give a valid notice as required by the said statute

anchor.surface_text: In order to put an end to the tenancy thus statutorily safeguarded the appellant has to follow the course prescribed by the amending statute and give a valid notice as required by the said statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutorily extended tenancy can only be terminated per new procedures in ss.5(2),(3)

holdings.text: the right of the appellant to eject the respondents would arise only on the termination of the tenancy and in the present case it would have been available to him on March 31, 1953 if the statutory provision had not in the meanwhile extended the life of the tenancy

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is necessary to bear in mind that the right of the appellant to eject the respondents would arise only on the termination of the tenancy and in the present case it would have been available to him on March 31, 1953 if the statutory provision had not in the meanwhile extended the life of the tenancy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ejectment right vests only upon actual tenancy termination, not notice alone; prevented by extension

holdings.text: before the right accrued to the appellant to eject the respondents amending Act XXXIII of 1952 stepped in and deprived him of that right by requiring him to comply with the statutory requirement as to a valid notice which has to be given for ejecting tenants

anchor.surface_text: Considered from this point of view, before the right accrued to the appellant to eject the respondents amending Act XXXIII of 1952 stepped in and deprived him of that right by requiring him to comply with the statutory requirement as to a valid notice which has to be given for ejecting tenants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amending Act prospectively conditioned unaccrued right to eject with new notice requirement

holdings.text: Where a statute operates in future it cannot be said to be retrospective merely because within the sweep of its operation all existing rights are included

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it is relevant to distinguish between an existing right and a vested right. Where a statute operates in future it cannot be said to be retrospective merely because within the sweep of its operation all existing rights are included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes vested from existing rights; future operation on existing rights is prospective

holdings.text: The position in regard to the operation of s. 5(1) of the amending Act with which we are concerned appears to us to be substantially similar

anchor.surface_text: The position in regard to the operation of s. 5 1  of the amending Act with which we are concerned appears to us to be substantially similar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies West v. Gwynne: future effect on existing leases not retrospective

holdings.text: this Court has approved of the decision of the full Bench of the Bombay High Court on that point in Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaberbhai Bhikabhai

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows own precedent approving application of s.34(2A) to cases where termination right matures post-amendment

holdings.text: we do not think that the position with regard to the provisions contained in s. 88 can be said to be analogous or similar to the position with regard to the relevant provisions of the amending Act XXXIII of 1952

anchor.surface_text: However, we do not think that the position with regard to the provisions contained in s. 88 can be said to be analogous or similar to the position with regard to the relevant provisions of the amending Act XXXIII of 1952 with which we are concerned in the present appeal.

The question which arises for our decision is whether the appellant is entiled to eject the respondents even without complying with the statutory requirement as to the valid notice prescribed by the amending Act XXXIII of 1952.
